articles.headline: At Netflix, a star and employees pressure a top executive over Dave Chappelle’s special.
articles.snippet: In a town-hall-style meeting on Friday, Ted Sarandos, a co-chief executive of Netflix, faced criticism from staff over Mr. Chappelle’s “The Closer.”
articles.abstract: In a town-hall-style meeting on Friday, Ted Sarandos, a co-chief executive of Netflix, faced criticism from staff over Mr. Chappelle’s “The Closer.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Tensions at Netflix continued to flare on Friday, 10 days after the release of a special by the comedian Dave Chappelle that critics inside and outside the company have described as promoting bigotry against transgender people.

articles.headline: Funding Fight Threatens Plan to Pump Billions Into Affordable Housing
articles.snippet: A federal voucher program is at risk of being sharply scaled back as the White House seeks to slash its social policy package to appease two centrist senators.
articles.abstract: A federal voucher program is at risk of being sharply scaled back as the White House seeks to slash its social policy package to appease two centrist senators.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Audrey Sylve, a retired bus driver, has spent 13 agonizing years on a waiting list for a federal voucher that would help cover rent for an apartment in one of America’s most expensive housing markets.

articles.headline: Money Floods the Race for Control of Congress, More Than a Year Early
articles.snippet: The main House war chests for both Democrats and Republicans have a combined $128 million in the bank — more than double the sum at this point in 2020.
articles.abstract: The main House war chests for both Democrats and Republicans have a combined $128 million in the bank — more than double the sum at this point in 2020.
articles.lead_paragraph: A dizzying amount of money is already pouring into the battles for the House and the Senate more than a year before the 2022 elections, as Republicans are bullish on their chances to take over both chambers in the first midterm election under President Biden, given the narrow margins keeping Democrats in power.

articles.headline: Instagram Struggles With Fears of Losing Its ‘Pipeline’: Young Users
articles.snippet: The app, hailed as Facebook’s growth engine, has privately wrestled with retaining and engaging teenagers, according to internal documents.
articles.abstract: The app, hailed as Facebook’s growth engine, has privately wrestled with retaining and engaging teenagers, according to internal documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Instagram reached one billion users in 2018, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, called it “an amazing success.” The photo-sharing app, which Facebook owns, was widely hailed as a hit with young people and celebrated as a growth engine for the social network.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel, Ryan Mac and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: In the Land of the Godfather Comes a Ban on Them
articles.snippet: Part of the Catholic church in Sicily has imposed a three-year prohibition on naming godparents, arguing that the tradition has become merely a way to fortify family ties — and mob ties, too.
articles.abstract: Part of the Catholic church in Sicily has imposed a three-year prohibition on naming godparents, arguing that the tradition has become merely a way to fortify family ties — and mob ties, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: CATANIA, Italy — The mother had prepared everything for the baptism. She dressed her infant son Antonio in a handmade satin suit with tails and a matching cream-colored top hat glittering with rhinestones. She hired the photographers and bought the baby a gold cross. She booked a big buffet lunch for the whole clan at the Copacabana.

articles.headline: Can a Carbon-Emitting Iron Ore Tycoon Save the Planet?
articles.snippet: Andrew Forrest made a mining fortune. Now he wants to lead a climate change revolution — and beat the fossil fuel giants along the way.
articles.abstract: Andrew Forrest made a mining fortune. Now he wants to lead a climate change revolution — and beat the fossil fuel giants along the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLOUDBREAK, Australia — Standing at the foot of a diesel truck as large as a dinosaur, Andrew Forrest juggled the microphone and then delivered the message that he knew the miners might see as a threat to their jobs and identities.

articles.headline: How 3 Strangers a World Away Came to the Rescue of a Badly Burned Afghan Girl
articles.snippet: The story of 8-year-old Asma, injured by a U.S. tear-gas canister, echoes the heartbreak and heroism of the 20-year American misadventure in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: The story of 8-year-old Asma, injured by a U.S. tear-gas canister, echoes the heartbreak and heroism of the 20-year American misadventure in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nabila had been fasting in the hope that God would get her family through the gates of Hamid Karzai International Airport. So when a tear-gas canister thrown by American forces trying to disperse the crowd hit her 8-year-old daughter, Asma, she was too weak to help.

articles.headline: 90 Seconds of Rage
articles.snippet: Inside, the violence was winding down. But outside, seven men found themselves at the center of breathtaking brutality.
articles.abstract: Inside, the violence was winding down. But outside, seven men found themselves at the center of breathtaking brutality.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside, the violence was winding down. But outside, seven men found themselves at the center of breathtaking brutality.
articles.byline: By Dan Barry, Alan Feuer and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Roblox, the Gaming Site, Wants to Grow Up Without Sacrificing Child Safety
articles.snippet: The company, which went public earlier this year, has lessons for other internet outfits aiming to attract younger users even as its own audience gets older.
articles.abstract: The company, which went public earlier this year, has lessons for other internet outfits aiming to attract younger users even as its own audience gets older.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As Dave Baszucki, the chief executive of the gaming company Roblox, took the stage at a conference hosted by his company on Thursday, he reflected on how much had changed for Roblox since its last in-person event two years ago.

articles.headline: At Axel Springer, Politico’s New Owner, Allegations of Sex, Lies and a Secret Payment
articles.snippet: A high-flying German media giant is ahead on digital media but seems stuck in the past when it comes to the workplace and deal-making.
articles.abstract: A high-flying German media giant is ahead on digital media but seems stuck in the past when it comes to the workplace and deal-making.
articles.lead_paragraph: A high-level editor at the powerful German tabloid Bild was trying to break things off with a woman who was a junior employee at the paper. He was 36. She was 25.

articles.headline: Washington Hears Echoes of the ’50s and Worries: Is This a Cold War With China?
articles.snippet: Incursions into Taiwan’s air zone, a space launch and what looked like a prisoner swap raise a question that is about more than just semantics. It could signal a dangerous new mind-set.
articles.abstract: Incursions into Taiwan’s air zone, a space launch and what looked like a prisoner swap raise a question that is about more than just semantics. It could signal a dangerous new mind-set.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Kevin Rudd, the former Australian prime minister and longtime China expert, told a German newsmagazine recently that a Cold War between Beijing and Washington was “probable and not just possible,” his remarks rocketed around the White House, where officials have gone to some lengths to squelch such comparisons.

articles.headline: Debate Weighs Price of Biden’s Big Plan vs. Not Acting
articles.snippet: Democrats are debating whether doing nothing will cost more than doing something to deal with climate change, education, child care, prescription drugs and more.
articles.abstract: Democrats are debating whether doing nothing will cost more than doing something to deal with climate change, education, child care, prescription drugs and more.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As lawmakers debate how much to spend on President Biden’s sprawling domestic agenda, they are really arguing about a seemingly simple issue: affordability.

articles.headline: Mass Abduction of U.S. Missionaries Startles Even Kidnap-Weary Haiti
articles.snippet: “Where is this country going?” Gang members seized 16 Americans and one Canadian, among them five children, as they visited an orphanage.
articles.abstract: “Where is this country going?” Gang members seized 16 Americans and one Canadian, among them five children, as they visited an orphanage.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Children on their way to school, street vendors selling their wares, priests mid-sermon — few Haitians, rich or poor, are safe from the gangs of kidnappers that stalk their country with near impunity. But the abduction this weekend of 17 people associated with an American missionary group as they visited an orphanage shocked officials for its brazenness.

articles.headline: China’s Economy Continues to Slow, Rattled by Real Estate and Energy
articles.snippet: Growth of 4.9 percent shows the country’s huge industrial sector has run into trouble. But exports and services are looking strong.
articles.abstract: Growth of 4.9 percent shows the country’s huge industrial sector has run into trouble. But exports and services are looking strong.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Steel mills have faced power cuts. Computer chip shortages have slowed car production. Troubled property companies have purchased less construction material. Floods have disrupted business in north-central China.

articles.headline: Why Public Health Faces a Crisis Across the U.S.
articles.snippet: An examination of hundreds of health departments around the country shows that the nation may be less prepared for the next pandemic than it was for the current one.
articles.abstract: An examination of hundreds of health departments around the country shows that the nation may be less prepared for the next pandemic than it was for the current one.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT ANGELES, Wash. — As she leaves work, Dr. Allison Berry keeps a vigilant eye on her rearview mirror, watching the vehicles around her, weighing if she needs to take a more circuitous route home. She must make sure nobody finds out where she lives.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: Nuclear Fusion Edges Toward the Mainstream
articles.snippet: Long-shot money is flowing into start-ups that seek the energy of the stars. Driving the investments is a rising alarm about global warming.
articles.abstract: Long-shot money is flowing into start-ups that seek the energy of the stars. Driving the investments is a rising alarm about global warming.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABINGDON, England — Harnessing fusion energy into something commercially viable — and maybe, ultimately, a clean source of power that replaces fossil fuels for centuries to come — has long been considered by some as the ultimate moonshot.

articles.headline: Inside the Real-Life Succession Battle at Scholastic
articles.snippet: The powerhouse children’s publisher, known for Harry Potter, had been passed from father to son until Iole Lucchese, a top executive, was given control.
articles.abstract: The powerhouse children’s publisher, known for Harry Potter, had been passed from father to son until Iole Lucchese, a top executive, was given control.
articles.lead_paragraph: When her phone buzzed on June 6, Iole Lucchese was still absorbing a shock that had come the day before. Her longtime boss, M. Richard Robinson Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the Scholastic publishing company, had died suddenly while taking a walk with one of his sons and his former wife on Martha’s Vineyard.
articles.byline: By Katherine Rosman and Elizabeth A. Harris

articles.headline: Colin Powell, Who Shaped U.S. National Security, Dies at 84
articles.snippet: A former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, secretary of state and national security adviser, Mr. Powell died of complications of Covid-19, his family said.
articles.abstract: A former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, secretary of state and national security adviser, Mr. Powell died of complications of Covid-19, his family said.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow the latest coverage of the death of Colin Powell.]

articles.headline: As Starbucks Workers Seek a Union, Company Officials Converge on Stores
articles.snippet: A push in the Buffalo area could produce the first union at company-owned stores in the U.S. But backers say moves by management are having a chilling effect.
articles.abstract: A push in the Buffalo area could produce the first union at company-owned stores in the U.S. But backers say moves by management are having a chilling effect.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — During her decade-plus at Starbucks, Michelle Eisen says she has endured her share of workplace stress. She points to the company’s increased use of productivity goals, inadequate attention to training and periods of understaffing or high turnover.
